Huairou District Beijing 101400 People's Republic of China c University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, People's Republic of China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 People's Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, People's Republic of China. Tel.: +86 10 69667699; fax: +86 10 69667653. Graphical abstract Cobalt-based catalysts containing 10wt.% Co supported on MCM-41 silica (MS) and commercial silica (CS) with different TiO2/SiO2 weight ratios (denoted as X) were prepared by the impregnation method. The characterization results indicated different existence form of Ti species on Co/Ti–MS–X and Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts, which greatly influenced the Co–support interaction, the dispersion and electronic property of cobalt species on catalysts. Highly dispersed Ti species were obtained on Ti–MS–X supports, which were beneficial to improve the dispersion of the cobalt species impregnated subsequently. Meanwhile, the Si atom in the network of MCM-41 silica could be substituted by the introduced Ti atoms, leading to the formation of TiOSi bond on Ti–MS–X supports. The strong Co–SiO2 interaction in Co/MS catalyst was effectively weakened due to the existence of Ti–O–Si structure in the catalysts promoted by low Ti loading. The reduction degree of cobalt species was therefore enhanced and the FTS activity was improved simultaneously. Moreover, the electron density of metallic cobalt was increased with the addition of TiO2 due to partial electrons transfer from support to Co via the Ti–O–Si structure, which affected the product distribution of FTS reaction. In the catalysts containing high Ti loading, the interaction between cobalt and Ti–MS–X supports was strengthened due to the agglomeration of TiO2, because of the strong interaction between cobalt and TiO2. Consequently, the reduction degree and FTS activity were retarded. In contrast, the obvious agglomeration of TiO2 was observed instead of the formation Ti–O–Si structure on Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts even at low Ti loading, which strengthened the Co–support interaction, resulting in a decrease in reduction degree and FTS activity. Keywords Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Cobalt-based catalysts MCM-41 silica Commercial silica TiO2 promotion 1 Introduction Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) over Co-based catalysts is one of the efficient routes for the conversion of syngas derived from coal, natural gas and biomass to liquid fuels [1]. It was general accepted that the FTS performance of a cobalt catalysts was mainly governed by its reducibility and dispersion, both of which were considered to be related to the nature of the support employed [2]. Al2O3 and TiO2, due to their desirable properties such as strong mechanical stability, high dispersion ability for active metals and low cost, are widely used as supports in cobalt-based catalysts [3,4]. However, the formation of non-reducible cobalt species, such as CoAl2O4 and CoTiO3, easily occurred on catalysts due to the strong metal–support interaction (SMSI), resulting in a decrease in reducibility and catalytic activity [5]. SiO2 is another support applied frequently in Co-based catalysts. The relatively weak Co–SiO2 interaction guaranteed the higher reduction degree of cobalt on one hand, while the poor dispersion of cobalt species was obtained on the other hand. In recent years, silica supports with mesoporous structure, such as MCM-41 and SBA-15, have been explored as potential materials for the preparation of supported cobalt catalysts due to the ordered mesoporous structure and higher surface areas than that of Al2O3, TiO2 and amorphous SiO2 [6–8]. The typically high surface area and uniform pore size distribution of mesoporous silica allowed a better control of the cobalt particle size compared to amorphous silica [6]. Furthermore, the narrow pore size distribution of mesoporous silica support can prevent the sintering of cobalt particles [7,8]. However, the poor mechanical and thermal stability of mesoporous silica limit its wide application. In order to overcome the drawbacks of conventional single oxide support, various integrated oxides such as Al2O3 SiO2, TiO2 SiO2 and ZrO2 SiO2 have been employed to modulate the structure and performance of catalysts [9–11]. The incorporation of secondary oxides into supports can improve the mechanical and thermal stability of catalysts. Moreover, the surface acidity of support and metal–support interaction also can be effectively modified [10,12–14]. In the specific case of TiO2–SiO2, the integrated oxides with different Ti/Si ratios show diverse acid types and acid strength, namely, in the SiO2-rich region Brønsted acidity would be developed while in the TiO2-rich region Lewis acidity would be developed [12]. The acid strength on support has a great influence on the product distribution in FTS reaction [13]. In addition to the modification of surface properties, the addition of TiO2 also affects the metal–support interaction and catalytic activity significantly. Soni et al. [10] confirmed the successful incorporation of Ti into SBA-15 framework on NiMo/TiSBA-15 catalysts with various Si/Ti molar ratios. Meanwhile the incorporation of Ti strengthened the metal–support interaction, which ultimately caused an increase in the dispersion of fresh and sulfide Mo species. Sheu et al. [14] proposed that the form of layer-like TiO2 clusters on SiO2 after incorporating 7% TiO2 (wt.%), which helped to anchor the subsequently incorporated palladium. Moreover, the addition of TiO2 also decreased electronic density of Pd clusters. The above results indicated that the incorporation of TiO2 into silica-based supports can improve the mechanical and thermal stability compared to pure silica, and modulate the surface acidity of support through altering the Ti/Si ratio. Meanwhile, the dispersion of metal is also enhanced by incorporating TiO2 into SiO2 supports. Therefore, dual oxides (TiO2 Al2O3, TiO2 SiO2) were also applied as supports to prepare Co-based catalysts [15–17]. Park et al. [15] considered that a trace amount of TiO2 (0.2–0.5%) into Co/Al2O3 catalysts could effectively improve CO conversion and C5 + selectivity due to the increased dispersion of cobalt clusters. Sukamon et al. [16] found that the addition of TiO2 (2, 5, 10wt.%) into Co/SiO2 catalysts significantly improved the FTS activity due to relatively high dispersion and reducibility of supported cobalt. Differently, Jongsomjit et al. [17] pointed out that the presence of TiO2 in the cobalt catalysts supported on mixed oxides TiO2–SiO2 would suppress the reducibility of cobalt species due to strong Co–TiO2 interaction and cause low FTS activity, while the C2–C5 selectivity substantially increased with the increasing amount of TiO2. These results show that the effects of TiO2 promotion on Co-based catalysts structure and FTS catalytic performance are controversial. In fact, the cobalt–support interaction and electronic property of cobalt species would greatly influence the reducibility of cobalt species and chemisorption of syngas on catalysts surface, and then affect catalytic activity and product distribution for FTS reaction. Meanwhile, the metal–support interaction, electronic property and dispersion of metal supported on Ti-MCM-41 are closely related with the existence form of Ti species [11]. However, there are limited reports about the variation of existence form of Ti species on Co/Ti-MCM-41 catalyst with respect to the TiO2 content, and the effects of existence form of Ti species on the catalysts structure and catalytic performance for FTS reaction. The present study attempts to investigate the promotion effects of TiO2 on the Co–SiO2 interaction, electronic properties of cobalt species and FTS performance. Thus, a series of cobalt catalysts (10wt.% Co) supported on MCM-41 and commercial silica doped with different amounts of TiO2 by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method were prepared. Multiple methods, namely, X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 physisorption analysis, UV–vis diffuse reflection spectroscopy (UV–vis DRS), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were utilized to characterize the catalysts. The FTS performance was tested in a fixed-bed reactor and correlated well with the characterization results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Support preparation MCM-41 silica (denoted as MS) was synthesized according to the method described in previous research [18], and the preparation process was detailed in the supporting information. Summarily, the Ti-containing MCM-41 materials were prepared by wet impregnation. 1g MCM-41 silica support was suspended in 10ml isopropanol (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China). A certain amount of titanium tetrabutoxide (TBOT, 99.0%) (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China) was added under stirring in a beaker for 2h, and then the above mixture including the beaker was transported into a stainless steel autoclave. 10ml isopropanol and 5ml deionized water were added into the interspace between the beaker and polyethylene liner. The autoclave was transferred into the oven and kept at 333K for 72h, after that the product was dried at 333K and calcined in air at 823K for 6h. The final product was defined as Ti–MS–X, where X indicated the weight ratios of TiO2/SiO2 (X =0/100, 5/100, 10/100, 25/100, 50/100). Commercial silica (denoted as CS) was applied as a reference and the same TiO2 introducing manner described earlier in the Ti–MS–X preparation was employed. The final product supported on commercial silica was defined as Ti–CS–X. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalysts of 10Co/Ti–MS–X and 10Co/Ti–CS–X with cobalt loading (10wt.%) were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method with aqueous solution containing the desired amount of cobalt nitrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.0%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China), then the samples were dried at 333K for 24h and calcined at 723K in air for 4h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization 2.3.1 XRD XRD patterns for the calcined samples were recorded with an advanced D8 powder diffractmeter (Bruker, Germany) with Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.154nm). The samples were scanned at small-angle from 0.5° to 10° (2θ) and at large-angle from 10° to 80° (2θ) with a step size of 0.02°, respectively. The crystallite phase was estimated with the data of Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS). 2.3.2 N2 physisorption analysis N2 physisorption experiment was conducted at 77K using a Surface Area and Porosimetry instrument (Micromeritics, Model 2420, USA). Prior to the experiment, the sample was degassed under vacuum at 363K for 1h and 623K for 6h. 2.3.3 UV–vis DRS The UV–vis diffuse reflection spectroscopy of the samples was recorded in the wavelength range 200–800nm using a Cary 300 spectrophotometer (Varian Associates, USA) equipped with a diffuse reflectance attachment. BaSO4 was used as a reference. 2.3.4 H2-TPR H2-TPR was performed in a dynamic analyzer (Micromeritics, Model 2920, USA). Prior to the H2-TPR measurement, the sample (150mg) was first flushed with Ar (flow rate 30ml/min) at 423K for 1h, and then cooled down to 323K. Subsequently, 5% H2/95% Ar (v/v) (flow rate 50ml/min) was flown through the catalyst while the temperature was increased to 1173K at a ramp rate of 10K/min. The outlet gas concentration was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3.5 H2-chemisorption H2 chemisorption was also performed using Micromeritics instrument (Model 2920, USA). Prior to the adsorption, the catalysts (250mg) were pre-treated in flowing He (flow rate 50ml/min) at 393K for 1h. Afterward, the samples were reduced in pure hydrogen (flow rate 50ml/min) at 673K for 12h and then cooled down to 323K. Subsequently, flowing argon (flow rate 30ml/min) was introduced to remove adsorption of weakly bound physisorbed species, and then H2 pluses were injected until the eluted peak area of consecutive pluses was constant. Finally, the temperature slowly increased to 1173K at a ramp rate of 10K/min. The variation of the outlet gas concentration was monitored by TCD. Isopropyl alcohol gel was used as a cold trap to remove the water formed during tests. It was assumed that the adsorption atom stoichiometriy is H:Co=1:1. The corrected dispersion (D Corr%) with reduction degree was calculated as follows [3]: D Corr % = Number of Co 0 atoms on surface ( Total number of Co atoms ) × ( Fractional degree of reduction ) × 100 % The corrected cobalt particles size (dp) was calculated from the cobalt dispersion by assuming spherical, uniform cobalt metal particles with site density of 14.6atoms/nm2. Thus, the cobalt metal particles size (dp) was calculated by the following formula, dp=96/D Corr% [3]. 2.3.6 NH3-TPD Temperature programmed NH3 desorption (NH3-TPD) was performed in dynamic analyzer (Micromeritics, Model 2920, USA). 250mg of catalyst was firstly pretreated in argon at 673K for 1h. NH3 was then injected to the catalyst after sample cooled down to 373K. The catalyst was swept using argon at 373K for 2h to remove the weakly adsorbed NH3. And then, the temperature was increased to 1173K at a ramp rate of 10K/min under argon (flow rate 50ml/min). Desorption of NH3 was detected by the dynamic analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3.7 FT-IR spectroscopy The IR spectra were recorded with a Vertex 70 FT-IR spectrometer (Bruker, Germany). The powdered sample was diluted with KBr and pressed into a translucent disk at room temperature. All spectra were taken in the range 4000–400cm−1 at a resolution of 4cm−1. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of CO adsorbed was also performed with a Vertex 70 FT-IR spectrometer. The catalyst (15mg) was pretreated in pure hydrogen (flow rate 20ml/min) for 2h at 673K, and then the temperature fell to 298K under flowing argon (flow rate 20ml/min) to prevent adsorption of weakly-bound species. The spectra were obtained at room temperature after the exposure of catalyst to CO at a rate 30ml/min for 1h, followed by sweeping in argon for 0.5h. The spectra of all samples were presented by subtracting the background spectrum. 2.3.8 XPS XPS was recorded on a VG Mutilab 2000 spectrometer (Bruker, Germany) using an Al Kα (h ν =1486.7eV) as X-ray source. To remove charging shifts and deal with Fermi edge coupling problems, binding energies (BE) were scaled against the peak of the C-(C, H) component coming from contamination carbon (set to 284.6eV). The pressure of the sample chamber was less than 2×10−8 Pa. 2.4 Catalysts evaluation Fischer–Tropsch synthesis was performed in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor with inner diameter of 12mm. The 2.5g of catalyst was packed in the isothermal region of reactor and the remaining volume of the reactor tube was filled with quartz granules in a size range of 40–60 mesh. All catalysts were reduced with H2 (space velocity of 1000L/kgcat/h) at 673K, 0.10MPa for 12h. The reaction conditions were maintained at 493 and 503K, P=2.0MPa, space velocity (SV)=2000L/kgcat/h, and H2/CO=2.0. A detailed description of the reactor and product analysis system has been provided elsewhere [19]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Support characterization 3.1.1 UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-DRS) The information about TiO2 dispersion in the series of Ti–MS–X and Ti–CS–X supports was obtained by UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (Fig. S1). As can be seen, no adsorption peaks from MCM-41 silica and commercial silica can be observed, which are transparent in this region of the UV–vis spectrum. Three adsorption peaks were observed at 210, 230 and 260nm over Ti–MS–X samples. Moreover, the intensity of adsorption peaks at 210 and 230nm was enhanced with the increasing TiO2 addition. For Ti–CS–X supports, in addition to the adsorption peaks at 230 and 260nm, two additional adsorption peaks were observed at 290 and 320nm. The adsorption peak at 210nm on Ti–MS–X supports corresponded to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transitions involving isolated Ti atoms in tetrahedral coordination [20], indicating the introduction of Ti species into the framework of MCM-41 silica. The adsorption peak at 230nm was assigned to isolated Ti atoms with distorted tetrahedral environment [21]. The adsorption peaks at about 260 and 290nm indicated the presence of some isolated Ti atoms in pentahedral and hexahedral coordination [20,22]. The adsorption peak located at 320nm on Ti–CS–X supports with high TiO2 content was associated to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer in bulk TiO2 [21]. The existence of peak at 320nm on Ti–CS–X showed that the incorporated Ti species were prone to agglomeration, and this effect was more pronounced at high Ti loading. Comparing with Ti–CS–X, an increase in intensity of adsorption peak at 210nm on Ti–MS–X supports suggested the increasing amount of Ti species into the framework of MCM-41 silica. Meanwhile, the absence of peak at 320nm indicated better dispersion of TiO2 on Ti–MS–X than that of Ti–CS–X supports. Lower surface area of commercial silica (379m2/g), relative to MCM-41 silica (1000m2/g), can be responsible for the agglomeration of TiO2 on Ti–CS–X, especially at high Ti loading. The results of UV-DRS confirmed that the successful incorporation of Ti species into MCM-41 framework and the amount of Ti species into framework increased with the increasing TiO2 content, which was well in line with the results of small-angle X-ray diffraction (Fig. S2). However, obvious agglomeration phenomenon of TiO2 was observed on Ti–CS–X supports. 3.1.2 FT-IR spectroscopy The FT-IR spectra of supports in the region of 4000–300cm−1 were shown in Fig. 1 . Three IR adsorption peaks at 1080, 812 and 470cm−1 were found in all samples, corresponding to the typical asymmetric stretching, symmetric stretching vibrations and bending vibrations of SiOSi of silica network, respectively. The band at 956cm−1 on Ti–MS–X supports probably arose from both Si–O–H and Si–O–Ti stretching vibrations [23]. As for the band at 956cm−1 on MCM-41 silica, it was usually assigned to Si–OH stretching vibration. Upon a small addition of TiO2, the intensity of adsorption peak at 956cm−1 was obviously weakened, and then oppositely increased with further addition of TiO2. Zheng et al. [24] considered that the introducing of TBOT precursor could react with Si–OH groups on MCM-41 to form SiOTi structure via cocondensation and hydrolization reactions, resulting in a loss of Si–OH on MCM-41 silica. Thus, the decreased intensity of peak at 956cm−1 on Ti–MS–X at low Ti loading resulted from the decreasing amount of Si–OH group, which was probably attributed to the cocondensation reaction between Si–OH and TBOT. Owing to overlapped adsorption peak position for TiOSi bond and SiOH bond, thus the increased intensity of adsorption peak located at 956cm−1 at high Ti loading could be attributed to the increasing amount of TiOSi bond on Ti–MS–X supports with the addition of TiO2 [25]. While no similar IR adsorption peak was observed on Ti–CS–X supports. The results of IR characterization demonstrated that Ti4+ could incorporate into the MCM-41 matrix and form TiOSi bond, which was in agreement with the results of UV-DRS and small-angle X-ray diffraction. Moreover, the amount of Si–OH on MCM-41 silica was obviously decreased by introducing a small addition of TiO2. However, no evidence of TiOSi bond was observed for Ti–CS–X supports. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 X-ray powder diffraction Fig. 2 presented the large-angle X-ray diffraction patterns of all samples. A set of diffraction peaks at 31.4°, 36.9°, 45.0°, 59.5° and 65.5° were assigned to the cubic phase Co3O4 (JCPDS 65-3103), which existed on all samples. The calculated Co3O4 crystallites size was listed in Table S1. As can be seen, the Co3O4 crystallite size of 10Co/Ti–MS–X gradually decreased with the increasing addition of TiO2, indicating that the addition of TiO2 could improve the dispersion of Co3O4. As for 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts, the Co3O4 crystallize size was decreased to 16.5nm for 10Co/Ti–CS–10/100, then increased to 18.8nm with the TiO2 content up to X =50/100. The variation of Co3O4 crystallite size of 10Co/Ti–CS–X samples showed that the dispersion state of Co3O4 particles was largely improved by a small addition of TiO2 and decreased at high Ti loading. 3.2.2 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS was employed to examine the surface analysis of fresh and reduced catalysts, and the results were shown in Fig S3 and Fig. 3 , respectively. As seen from Fig. S3, the binding energies (BE) at 458.5, 103.5 and 532.9eV of 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts are assigned to Ti2p3/2, Si2p and O1s respectively, which approximately equal to the BE of pure TiO2 (458.7eV) and SiO2 (103.5 and 533.0eV) [19,26]. In the Ti-containing samples, the O1s core-level spectra could be deconvoluted into two lines. The higher values of O1s BE (∼533eV) are assigned to O atoms close to Si cations (OSi), and the lower ones (∼530eV) can be corresponded to O atoms close to Ti cations [27]. In comparison with 10Co/MS, the BE of Si2p and OSi1S in 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts gradually shifted to lower value with the addition of TiO2, while an opposite binding-energy shift (459.2–459.6eV) was observed on Ti2p. Grohmann et al. [28] considered that core-level binding-energy shift was caused by variation of the electron density around the central atom. The electron density of the central atoms is greatly influenced by the electronegativity of the atoms surrounded. Namely, the greater the electronegativity of the adjacent atoms, the lower the electron density of the central atom due to partial electron transfer [19]. It is well known that the electronegativity of Ti atoms (1.54) is much lower than that of Si atoms (1.98). Once the formation of Ti–O–Si structure was achieved, the electron density of Ti species would decrease owing to partial electron transfer from Ti species to Si–O group. Thus the BE variation in 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts indicated the successful incorporation of Ti species into the network of 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts and formation of Ti–O–Si structure, resulting in electron-rich state of Si–OSi group but electron-deficient state of Ti species. Consequently, the BE of Si2p and OSi1s decreased, while the Ti2p BE increased. Comparing with 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts, it seems that the addition of TiO2 has no obvious influence on the BE variation of Ti2p, Si2p and O1s in 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts. Implied from Co2p photoelectron peak, BE of Co2p3/2 around 780eV is assigned to the fully oxidized Co3O4 denoted as Co(I) [29], and the satellite peak at somewhat higher BE around 785eV can be attributed to the amorphous-phase Co2+ species denoted as Co(II) [30]. The presence of satellite peak was generally related to the difficult reducibility of cobalt species by forming a strong metal–support interaction, such as cobalt aluminate and cobalt silicate [30]. The surface composition of samples was listed in Table S1. With the increasing TiO2 content, Co(II)/Co(I) ratios on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts varied by showing the shape of an anti-volcano curve, while increasing ratios were observed on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts. As for 10Co/Ti–MS–X, high Co(II)/Co(I) ratio (0.49) on 10Co/MS could be attributed to the formation of cobalt silicate. While the Co(II)/Co(I) ratio decreased to a lower value (0.42) on 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100, indicating that a small addition of TiO2 could inhabit the formation of cobalt silicate. The increasing Co(II)/Co(I) ratios on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts showed that the amount of non-reducible cobalt species increased with the increase of TiO2 content. The surface analysis of the reduced catalysts was also performed by XPS (Fig. 3). Comparing with fresh catalysts, similar binding energy variation of Si2p, O1s and Ti2p was observed on reduced catalysts. As can be seen from the fitted Co2p spectrum, the peak observed at ∼778eV is usually assigned to Co0, denoted as Co(III), while the peak at ∼781eV corresponds to Co2+ [31], denoted as Co(IV). The Co2p spectrum indicated the coexistence of metallic cobalt and partially reduced Co2+ species. It should be noted that O1s binding energy of reduced catalysts was lower than that of fresh catalysts, which was attributed to the presence of lower O1s BE in partially reduced cobalt oxides in reduced catalysts (such as CoO). The ratios of Co(III)/Co(IV) was calculated and listed in Table S1. Comparing with 10Co/MS catalyst, an obvious increase in Co(III)/Co(IV) ratio (0.36–0.56) was observed in 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100 catalyst, while an opposite trend was presented on catalysts with the further addition of TiO2. As for 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts, the Co(III)/Co(IV) ratios gradually decreased with the addition of TiO2 (0.53–0.31). In fact, higher Co(III)/Co(IV) ratios means lager amount of Co0 but less amount of partially reduced Co2+ species in catalysts. The variation of Co(III)/Co(IV) ratios indicated that a small addition of TiO2 into 10Co/MS catalysts would restrain the formation of non-reducible cobalt species and promote the reduction of cobalt oxides, while this effect was inhibited at high Ti loading. On the contrary, the reduction of cobalt oxides on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts was suppressed by the incorporation of TiO2. Moreover, it was also found that the peak corresponding to Co0 (∼778eV) shifted to lower binding energy with the addition of TiO2. Combining with the previous results, this shift indicated the increasing electron density of Co0 with the addition of TiO2. The results of XPS analysis showed that the addition of TiO2 into 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts improved the electron density of Co0, and simultaneously a small addition of TiO2 would promote the reduction of cobalt species, while the reduction of cobalt species in 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts was suppressed with the addition of TiO2. 3.2.3 CO-DRIFTS Fig. 4 illustrated the spectra of CO adsorbed on the surface of reduced catalysts. The bands located at 1870 and 1790cm−1 corresponding to the stretching vibrations of bridged-bonded CO on cobalt sites, can be observed for all the catalysts. For 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts, the intensity of bands at 1870 and 1790cm−1 obviously increased with the increase of TiO2 content, indicating that CO adsorption was improved by the addition of TiO2. Similar trend was observed on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts with the TiO2 content up to X =25/100. In addition, a red shift of CO adsorption peak was presented on the 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts with the addition of TiO2, while the peak position for adsorbed CO on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts remained almost unchanged. The formation of bridged bonded CO on cobalt metal sites can be explained by the σ-Π binding model [32]. When CO adsorbed on metal clusters, electron transfer occurs from the d-orbital of metal to antibonding π* orbital of CO [33]. High electron density on metal sites causes high back donating from metal to the CO π* orbital. This back donating weakens the CO bond of CO adsorbed on metal, resulting in a red shift of the CO stretching frequency [34]. As shown in Fig. 4, the red shift for the adsorbed CO on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts indicated that CO molecules accepted additional electrons from cobalt metal. It should be noted that the electron density of metal is closely related with the electronic property of atoms or groups surrounded [35,36]. Ramaker et al. [35] proposed that the composition of the support greatly affected the electronic property of support oxygen around Pt metal particles, which could change the electron density of Pt through electron transfer with oxygen atom. Visser et al. [36] also found that the addition of alkali or earth alkali metal ions into Pt/H-Y catalysts could improve the electron density of support oxygen atoms around Pt metal particles, resulting in the electron-rich state of Pt due to electron transfer from oxygen atom. Combining results of XPS analysis, it is reasonable that the formation of TiOSi bond on 10Co/Ti–MS–X lead to the formation of high electron-rich Si–O group. Thus, the red-shift of adsorbed CO on the 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts may be attributed to the electron transfer from electron-rich Si–O group to metallic cobalt. Meanwhile, high electron density of metallic cobalt also weakened the CO bond of adsorbed CO and conduced to the dissociation of CO on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts [34]. The results of CO-DRIFTS indicated that the incorporated TiO2 not only improved the CO adsorption capacity, but also changed the electronic property of metallic cobalt on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts. 3.2.4 Reduction behavior of catalysts The reducibility of catalysts was studied by H2-TPR (see Fig. 5 and Table 1 ). Three major peaks were observed at different regions, i.e., a relatively sharp peak at around 520–570K (denoted as I), a broad one centered at about 600K (denoted as II) and finally a peak at 800–1100K (denoted as III). It is well known that the peaks at 500–700K are typically assigned to the two-step reduction of Co3O4 (Co3O4→CoO and CoO→Co0), and H2 consumption ratio for these two-step reduction is 1:3 [37]. The higher-temperature peak (>800K) is usually corresponded to the reducibility of non-reducible cobalt species. As illustrated in Fig. 5a, in addition to a main reduction peak at about 600K, another peak centered at about 1000K (III) on 10Co/MS catalyst, assigned to the reduction of cobalt silicate compound, was observed. The formation of cobalt silicate compound indicated a strong interaction between cobalt and MCM-41 support. In contrast, the reduction peak at lower temperature (600K) of 10Co/MS catalyst progressively transited to a doublet formed by peaks I and II after TiO2 addition, simultaneously accompanied by a sequential shift of reduction peak position. Upon the addition of a small amount of TiO2 into 10Co/MS catalyst, the reduction peak at about 600K gradually shifted to lower temperature. Moreover, the peak at 800–1100K declined with the addition of TiO2 and completely disappeared for 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100 catalyst. With the further addition of TiO2, the peak centered at ∼600K shifted to higher temperature and transformed into a broad reduction peak at 700–1100K. As shown in Fig. 5b, two peaks centered at 570K and 600K on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts were assigned to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co0 respectively. When the TiO2 was added to the 10Co/CS catalyst, the reduction peak at 600K shifted to high temperature and the peak area increased as the increase of TiO2 content, indicating the reducibility of cobalt species was suppressed by the addition of TiO2. The H2 consumption of all catalysts within the temperature range 500–700K was listed in Table S2. The deconvolution of the reduction peak centered at 600K for 10Co/MS catalyst resulted in a peak II/peak I area ratio of 2.98, in agreement with the theoretical value of 3. While lower total H2 consumption (1.59mmol/gcat) compared with the theoretical value of Co3O4 to Co0 (2.26mmol/gcat), indicating partial reduction of cobalt species on 10Co/MS catalyst. With the increase of TiO2 content, the total H2 consumption increased firstly and reached a maximum value (2.06mmol/gcat) on 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100 catalyst, then decreased with further addition of TiO2. While the decreased peak II/peak I ratio and total H2 consumption were observed on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts with the increasing TiO2 content. As seen from the results of TPR, the reduction peak around 1000K on 10Co/MS catalyst was attributed to the formation of non-reducible cobalt silicate compound on catalyst, which depended on the reaction of cobalt species and surface silanol groups of the silica support [38,39]. The FT-IR results indicated that the amount of Si–OH group was obviously decreased by a small addition of TiO2 into MCM-41 silica, thus the formation of cobalt silicate was also suppressed, resulting in a maximum reduction degree (91.3%) on 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100. It is clear that the presence of stable CoTiO3 compound on Co/TiO2 catalyst due to strong Co–TiO2 interaction makes the cobalt species difficult to be reduced at low temperature [40]. In the present work, the agglomeration of TiO2 occurred on catalysts when promoted with high TiO2 content, especially for 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts. Thus, the decreased reduction degree on catalysts was probably attributed to the formation of non-reducible cobalt species due to strong Co–TiO2 interaction. In addition, the addition of TiO2 also influenced the dispersion of cobalt metal particles. It was found that the uniform dispersion of TiO2 on catalysts could help to improve the dispersion of metal particles [12,17]. Therefore, the relatively high dispersion of cobalt metal particles on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts was explained by the fact that the well dispersed TiO2 clusters on catalysts anchored metallic cobalt and maintained it in a high dispersion state during calcination. Similarly, the dispersion of cobalt metal particles was largely improved by the addition of a small amount of TiO2 into 10Co/CS catalyst, resulting in a minimum value in particle size at 10Co/Ti–CS–10/100 (10.0nm). However, the agglomeration of TiO2 at high Ti loading suppressed the dispersion of cobalt species. 3.2.5 Chemisorption behavior of catalysts H2 adsorption and activation on all catalysts was shown in Fig. S4. As can be seen, two hydrogen desorption peaks can be found in all catalyst except 10Co/CS catalyst, indicating two kinds of hydrogen adsorption sites on the reduced cobalt catalysts. One peak was located at about 353K and the other was centered at approximately 800K. The H2 uptakes (<673K) of all catalysts were listed in Table 1. The H2 uptakes on all catalysts varied by showing the shape of a volcano curve with respect to the TiO2 content, achieving a maximum value with the TiO2 content up to X =10/100. A directly proportional relationship between hydrogen adsorption amount and active metal sites was proposed. Thus, it could be concluded that more active sites are formed on catalysts doped with the TiO2 content of X =10/100. Combining with the TPR results, higher H2 uptake (89.59μmol/g) on 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100 catalyst was attributed to the higher reduction degree (91.3%). In the case of 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts, although a slight decrease in reduction degree (5.3%) of 10Co/Ti–CS–10/100 in contrast to that of 10Co/CS catalyst (92.8%), higher H2 uptake (71.35μmol/g) over 10Co/Ti–CS–10/100 catalyst was probably attributed to the smaller cobalt metal particles size. Then the decreased reduction degree and cobalt dispersion at high Ti loading led to less available active sites for the adsorption of hydrogen molecules, resulting in a minimum value (29.33μmol/g) at 10Co/Ti–CS–50/100 catalyst. In addition, it was also found that the hydrogen desorption peak on 10Co/Ti–MS–X shifted to higher temperature with the addition of TiO2. Ishihara et al. [41] considered that hydrogen desorption was affected by the electron density of active metal. Namely, the higher the electron density of active metal due to additional electrons transfer from the adjacent electron-donating atoms (groups), the higher hydrogen desorption temperature. In our work, an upward shift in the hydrogen desorption temperature on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts, indicated the increased electron density of cobalt metal with the increasing TiO2 content. This suggested that cobalt metal accepted additional electrons from Ti–MS–X supports, which was consistent with the results of CO-DRIFTS. The acidity of catalysts was characterized by NH3-TPD and the results were listed in Table 1. Lower ammonia uptake in catalysts supported on pure silica indicated less acid sites on catalysts. While increasing ammonia uptake on Ti-containing catalysts suggested that the addition of TiO2 can generate remarkably high acidity and strong acid strength, and this effect was more pronounced on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts. Similar results have also been found in other works [14,15]. 3.2.6 Fischer–Tropsch synthesis performance evaluation The catalyst performance was evaluated in a fixed bed reactor and the results were shown in Table 2 . As can be seen, CO conversion over catalysts increased with the TiO2 content up to X =10/100, reaching a maximum value, then decreased with further addition of TiO2. The selectivity to gaseous and light hydrocarbons (methane and C2–C4) was suppressed, whereas that to heavy hydrocarbons (C+ 5) was enhanced by incorporating a small amount of TiO2 into catalysts. While an opposite change in product distribution was observed on catalysts with the further addition of TiO2. It is well known that the FTS catalytic activity closely relates with the number of metal active sites on catalysts surface. The higher reduction degree and cobalt dispersion on cobalt catalysts provide more cobalt metal centers for FTS reaction and lead to higher catalytic activity [42]. Implied from the results of H2-TPD and H2-TPR, both cobalt metal dispersion and reduction degree of 10Co/Ti–MS–X were obviously improved by a small addition of TiO2, reaching a higher value with the TiO2 content up to X =10/100. Thus, higher FTS activity on 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100 catalyst was attributed to more cobalt metal active sites on catalyst. Then, the decreasing reduction degree on catalysts with high TiO2 content caused a loss in metal active sites, which suppressed catalytic activity. Although slightly decreased reduction degree on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts at low Ti loading, higher CO conversion over 10Co/Ti–CS–10/100 was probably attributed to well-dispersed cobalt metal particles. At high Ti loading, lower reduction degree and dispersion of cobalt species on catalysts suppressed CO conversion. The influence of cobalt metal particles size on surface-specific activity (turnover frequency, TOF) for all catalyst was shown in Fig. 6 and Table 2. In the case of 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts, the value of TOF gradually increased within the cobalt particles size from 7.3 to 8.3nm and kept essentially unchanged with the further increase in cobalt particles size. In contrast, only a constant TOF was observed on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts with the cobalt metal particle size ranged from 11.5 to 19.5nm. In fact, cobalt metal particle size has a great effect on the TOF of Fischer–Tropsch synthesis reaction. Park et al. [43] as well as Fishcher et al. [44] found that the TOF continuously increased with the increasing cobalt particles size up to 8–9nm and kept a constant value for cobalt crystallites above 9nm. The lower reducibility of cobalt species and structure sensitivity usually have been suggested as the causes for lower TOF value for catalysts with small cobalt particles size [43,44]. The cobalt particle size tested in our present study is ∼8nm, which is agreement with the results reported in Park et al. and Fishcher et al. Combining with the results of TPR, lower TOF value for 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts with small cobalt particles size (7.3–7.8nm) at high Ti loading was probably attributed to lower reduction degree. A constant value of TOF was observed on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts with the cobalt particles size ranged from 11.5nm to 19.5nm, indicating that FTS reaction was structure insensitivity within this particles size range. Van Santen [45] and Wilson et al. [46] hypothesized that the CO activation would easily occur on cobalt metal particles size below 15nm. Thus, lower activation ability of CO would be observed on catalysts with large cobalt particle size, such as 10Co/CS (19.5nm) and 10Co/Ti–CS–5/100 (15.6nm), resulting in lower CO adsorption amount on catalysts in agreement with the results of CO-DRIFTS analysis. Furthermore, the lower activation ability of CO on theses catalysts also suppressed FTS activity. The product distributions of all catalysts were shown in Fig. 7a and b. As can be seen, the selectivity to methane and C2–C4 was suppressed, whereas that to heavy hydrocarbons C5 + selectivity and the ratio of olefin to paraffin (C2 =C4 =/C2 0C4 0) was enhanced on catalysts with the TiO2 content up to X =10/100. While an opposite change trend was observed on catalysts at high Ti loading. It is well known that the surface H/C ratio plays an important role in determining the product distributions of the Co-based FTS catalysts [47,48]. Higher hydrogen availability would increase the hydrogenation ability and lead to the high light hydrocarbons selectivity, such as CH4 and C2–C4. While high carbon concentration would increase the carbon chain probability and result in more long-chain hydrocarbons [49]. In the present study, the results of H2-TPD and CO-DRIFTS showed that adsorption capability of H2 and CO was improved by a small addition of TiO2, while the adsorption of H2 was suppressed at high Ti loading. As confirmed in CO-DRIFTS, a red-shift of CO adsorption peak on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts, which implied an electron enrichment of cobalt species on catalysts. It should be noted that the electron enrichment state of cobalt species would facilitate CO dissociation adsorption and suppress H2 adsorption. Thus, a low H/C ratio was presented on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts surface, which could explain high heavy hydrocarbons selectivity (C5 +%) but low selectivity to light fraction (CH4% and C2–4%) on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts at low Ti loading. However, the reason for a similar product distribution on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts was not clear at present. At high Ti loading, a suppressed H2 adsorption but enhanced CO adsorption on catalysts caused low H/C ratios on catalysts surface, which was not consistent with high CH4 but low C5 + selectivity on catalysts. In fact, FTS product distribution was also influenced by the acidic property of catalysts [50,51]. Yang et al. [51] found that increasing light fraction of FTS product distributions after introducing ZSM-5 zeolite into Co/SiO2 catalysts, which was attributed to the cracking of long-chain hydrocarbons on the strong acidic sites of ZSM-5 zeolite. It was found the increasing acidic sites on Ti-doping catalysts with the increasing TiO2 content characterized by NH3-TPD (listed in Table 1), especially for 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts. Thus, higher selectivity to CH4 on catalysts with high TiO2 content was probably ascribed to the cracking of heavy hydrocarbons with the presence of strong acid sites on catalysts, which led to a certain amount of CH4 and C2–C4 light hydrocarbons. The variation of CO conversion with the time on the stream (TOS) at 493 and 503K respectively are shown in Fig. 7c and d. As can be seen, a slight drop (∼1%) in CO conversion was observed on 10Co/CS catalysts at 493K after 100h, and even though at 503K only ∼2% CO conversion drop was presented. The increasing CO conversion was accompanied by the promotion with a small amount of TiO2, resulting in higher CO conversion over 10Co/Ti–CS–10/100 catalyst. With the further addition of TiO2, CO conversion decreased to a minimum (17.1%) over 10Co/Ti–CS–50/100 catalyst, moreover the CO conversion on 10Co/Ti–CS–50/100 catalyst dropped slowly from 18.6% to 17.1% after 100h. There is no obvious activity drop was observed 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts with the time of stream, indicating good FTS reaction stability. The cobalt-based catalysts supported on mesoporous silica usually display poor stability due to the destruction of mesoporous structure under high temperature and high steam pressure in FTS reaction process [52]. In our study, an obvious drop in CO conversion was also observed on 10Co/MS catalyst, especially at high temperature (503K). In contrast, the enhanced stability was observed on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts (except 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100), indicating that the addition of TiO2 could improve the catalysts stability. It should be noted that an obvious drop in CO conversion was observed on 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100 catalyst. In 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100 catalyst, high CO conversion produced high water steam pressure, which accelerated to the destruction of mesoporous silica, resulted in an obvious activity drop in initial hours. Meanwhile, the re-oxidation of cobalt active species by water was also responsible for the drop of CO conversion [53,54]. In summary, the proper amount of TiO2 into 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalyst would help to improve the catalysts stability. As seen from the characterization results, different local structure of TiO2 was exhibited on MCM-41 silica and commercial silica supports, which greatly influenced the cobalt–support interaction and the electron density of cobalt species on catalysts. The formation of cobalt silicate was observed on 10Co/MS catalyst due to strong cobalt–support interaction effects. However, these effects were weakened by a small addition of TiO2, which obviously suppressed the formation of cobalt silicate and improved the reducibility of catalysts, especially for 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100. With the increasing TiO2 content, the incorporated Ti species were prone to agglomerate into bulk TiO2 on catalysts at high Ti loading, e.g. 10Co/Ti–MS–50/100. Owing to strong Co–TiO2 interaction, the interaction between cobalt and Ti–MS–X support was strengthened due to the agglomeration of TiO2, resulting in the decreased reduction degree at high Ti loading. In addition, the incorporated Ti species also gave rise to the electron density change of cobalt species. The characterization results (FT-IR, UV-DRS and XPS) indicated that the Si atom of MCM-41 framework could be substituted by the incorporated Ti atom and form Ti–O–Si structure. Owing to higher electronegativity of Si atom than that of Ti atom, the substitution of Si by Ti caused an electron-rich state of Si–O group due to partial electrons transfer. The results of XPS and CO-DRIFTS indicated that the addition of TiO2 into 10Co/MS catalyst could improve the electron density of cobalt metal, which was probably attributed to the electrons transfer from electron-rich state of Si–O group. In contrast, easier agglomeration of TiO2 was observed on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts, accompanied with the decreased reduction degree with the increasing TiO2 addition due to strong Co–TiO2 interaction. Based on above conclusions, a model of the surface structure of fresh and activated catalysts with TiO2/SiO2 weight ratios of 0, 10/100 and 50/100 was presented on Fig. 8 . 4 Conclusion In this study, different amount of TiO2 was incorporated into MCM-41 silica (MS) and commercial silica (CS), then 10% (wt.%) cobalt was impregnated on above supports to prepare Co-based catalysts for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis reaction. The results of characterizations (FT-IR, XPS, TPR, and XRD) indicated that the cobalt–support interaction, the electronic property of cobalt species and FTS performance were influenced by the existence form of Ti species on catalysts. The following conclusions were drawn from the present study. (1) The addition of TiO2 could effectively modulate interaction between cobalt and support. Lower reduction degree and FTS reaction activity was observed on 10Co/MS catalyst due to strong interaction between cobalt and MCM-41 silica. While this strong interaction was obviously weakened by a small addition of TiO2, reaching a maximum value of reduction degree and catalytic activity on 10Co/Ti–MS–10/100 catalyst. Contrarily, large incorporation amount of TiO2 decreased the reduction degree and FTS performance of catalysts. It was also found that better dispersion of TiO2 on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts conduced to improving the dispersion of cobalt species. In contrast, an obvious agglomeration of TiO2 on 10Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts, especially at high Ti loading, strengthened the Co–support interaction, resulting in a decrease in reduction degree and FTS activity. (2) The incorporation of TiO2 also altered the electron density of cobalt species. The results of XPS and CO-DRIFTS indicated an electron enrichment of cobalt species on 10Co/Ti–MS–X catalysts with the modification of TiO2. The electron rich state of cobalt species would suppress H2 adsorption and decrease the H/C ratio on the surface of catalysts, resulting in low CH4 but high heavy hydrocarbons selectivity at low Ti loading. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt-based catalysts containing 10wt.% Co supported on MCM-41 silica (MS) and commercial silica (CS) with different TiO2/SiO2 weight ratios (denoted as X) were prepared by the impregnation method. The characterization results indicated different existence form of Ti species on Co/Ti–MS–X and Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts, which greatly influenced the Co–support interaction, the dispersion and electronic property of cobalt species on catalysts. Highly dispersed Ti species were obtained on Ti–MS–X supports, which were beneficial to improve the dispersion of the cobalt species impregnated subsequently. Meanwhile, the Si atom in the network of MCM-41 silica could be substituted by the introduced Ti atoms, leading to the formation of TiOSi bond on Ti–MS–X supports. The strong Co–SiO2 interaction in Co/MS catalyst was effectively weakened due to the existence of Ti–O–Si structure in the catalysts promoted by low Ti loading. The reduction degree of cobalt species was therefore enhanced and the FTS activity was improved simultaneously. Moreover, the electron density of metallic cobalt was increased with the addition of TiO2 due to partial electrons transfer from support to Co via the Ti–O–Si structure, which affected the product distribution of FTS reaction. In the catalysts containing high Ti loading, the interaction between cobalt and Ti–MS–X supports was strengthened due to the agglomeration of TiO2, because of the strong interaction between cobalt and TiO2. Consequently, the reduction degree and FTS activity were retarded. In contrast, the obvious agglomeration of TiO2 was observed instead of the formation Ti–O–Si structure on Co/Ti–CS–X catalysts even at low Ti loading, which strengthened the Co–support interaction, resulting in a decrease in reduction degree and FTS activity.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of TiO2 promotion on the structure and performance of silica-supported cobalt-based catalysts for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis
